summary: In November 1963, South Korea demonstrated significant concern and response following President John F. Kennedy's assassination. High-ranking officials, including Chairman PAK and Vice Chairman SIN, traveled to Washington D.C. to attend the funeral, with security arrangements coordinated by U.S. authorities. Memorial rites were conducted in Seoul, and messages of condolence were sent by South Korean officials, who also ordered flags to be flown at half-mast. The South Korean Ambassador in Washington reported on the positive reactions to the South Korean President's visit to the U.S. amidst the tragedy. The Prime Minister of South Korea, KIM (YO'NG CHO'L), also attended the funeral and sought meetings with Secretary Rusk and President Johnson. Simultaneously, South Korea was preparing for National Assembly General Elections, raising concerns about potential election violations and political stability. Intelligence reports also mentioned a potential coup in South Korea around the time of the assassination.
significance: South Korea's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in its immediate and high-level response to President Kennedy's death, including sending representatives to the funeral and holding memorial services. The documents also suggest a period of political instability and election preparations in South Korea concurrent with the assassination, raising potential concerns about the country's internal affairs during this sensitive time. The presence of South Korean officials at the funeral and their interactions with U.S. leaders highlight the diplomatic relationship between the two countries.
